choices.text: Thalassemia major
Thalassemia minor
Iron deficiency anemia​
Anemia of chronic disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with the following laboratory values: hemoglobin 9gm%, MCV is 55%, RBC is 4.5 million/mm3. There is no history of blood transfusion. What is the most likely diagnosis out of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalassemia minor

  Option B:

Thalassemia major patient presents with severe anemia and cannot survive without blood transfusion, so this option can be easily ruled out. For other options, Mentzer index is useful for differentiating between thalassemia minor and iron deficiency anemia.

  Thalassemia minor often presents with mild to moderate anemia and a low MCV. The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV divided by the RBC count, is less than 13 in thalassemia minor.

Explanation:

Option A. Patients with thalassemia major typically present with severe anemia requiring regular blood transfusions. The degree of anemia in the vignette is not consistent with thalassemia major.

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic and hypochromic anemia. The Mentzer index is generally greater than 13, which is not the case here.

Option D. Anemia of chronic disease usually presents with normocytic or sometimes microcytic anemia, but it is often characterized by a normal or increased storage iron level, which can be evaluated by serum ferritin.

Educational Objective:

When presented with mild to moderate microcytic anemia and an MCV/RBC count that yields a Mentzer index of less than 13, thalassemia minor is a likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Beta thalassemia trait
Sickle cell anemia
Hereditory spherocytosis
G6 PD deficiency

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with mild anemia noted on routine screening. She reports a family history of anemia but has no significant personal medical history. She denies any symptoms of anemia. A hemoglobin electrophoresis is performed, showing an increased HbA2 level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta thalassemia trait

 

Option A:

 

Beta thalassemia trait is characterized by a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to reduced (β+) or absent (β0) production of β-globin chains. Compensatory increase in HbA2 (α2δ2) is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Hemoglobin electrophoresis usually reveals an increase in HbA2 (α2δ2) to 4% to 8% of the total hemoglobin (nor¬mal, 2.5% ± 0.3%), which is a reflection of an elevated ra¬tio of δ-chain to β-chain synthesis. HbF levels are generally normal or occasionally slightly increased

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sickle cell anemia is characterized by a mutation in the beta-globin gene that leads to the production of hemoglobin S. Hemoglobin electrophoresis in sickle cell anemia typically shows a predominance of HbS and possibly elevated HbF but not HbA2.

 

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis is a disorder of the red blood cell membrane leading to spherical erythrocytes and hemolytic anemia. It does not involve abnormalities in hemoglobin synthesis or elevated HbA2 levels.

 

Option D. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked enzymatic defect leading to hemolytic anemia under conditions of oxidative stress. It is not associated with an increase in HbA2 on electrophoresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals increased HbA2 levels, it is indicative of beta thalassemia trait, reflecting an imbalance in globin chain production.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 641

choices.text: Deletion of 4 alpha chains
Deletion of 3 alpha chains
Deletion of 2 alpha chains
Deletion of 1 alpha chain

questions.text: HbH is formed due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deletion of 3 alpha chains

Option B:

Deletion of 3 alpha chains leads to the formation of HbH disease. HbH is composed of four beta-globin chains and is formed in response to the lack of sufficient alpha chains.

Explanation:

Option A. Deletion of all 4 alpha chains typically results in hydrops fetalis and is usually incompatible with life; hence it does not lead to the formation of HbH.

Option D. Deletion of 1 alpha chain usually causes no significant clinical symptoms and is known as silent carrier state; it does not lead to HbH formation.

Option C: Deletion of 2 alpha chains often causes a milder form of alpha thalassemia, known as alpha thalassemia trait or alpha thalassemia minor, not typically associated with the formation of HbH.

Educational Objective:

HbH disease is caused by the deletion of three alpha-globin genes, which leads to an excess of beta-globin chains that form the abnormal hemoglobin H (beta4).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 645

choices.text: Stability
Function
Affinity
Solubility

questions.text: What is affected in sickled hemoglobin; HbS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Solubility

Option D:

Solubility is the property most affected by the mutation causing HbS. Under deoxygenated conditions, HbS polymerizes, leading to the formation of insoluble fibers that deform the red blood cells into a sickle shape.

Explanation:

Option A. Stability refers to the hemoglobin molecule's resistance to denaturation and degradation. While HbS can be less stable under deoxygenating conditions, this is not the primary issue.

 Option B. Function pertains to the ability of hemoglobin to carry oxygen. HbS can still carry oxygen, but the sickling process can hinder its release to tissues.

Option C. Affinity refers to the hemoglobin's ability to bind oxygen. HbS has a slightly different oxygen affinity compared to normal hemoglobin, but again, this is not the main problem.

Educational Objective:

Sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) is primarily characterized by reduced solubility under deoxygenated conditions, leading to polymerization and sickling of red blood cells. This results in vaso-occlusive crises and chronic hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 638

questions.text: A 6-years-old child belonging to Punjabi family with past history of blood transfusions presented with hemoglobin 3.5 g/dl, MCV – 30 fl, MCHC – 20. Peripheral smear findings of microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cell and reduced osmotic fragility. What is the he probable diagnosis of patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Beta thalassemia

 

Option B:

Friends, let’s get the answer of this question in a methodical manner. The clues in the question:

Reduced values of MCV and MCHC: microcytic hypochromic anemia (G6PD deficiency is ruled out)

Age of presentation and ethnicity: 6-year-old and Punjabi ethnicity

History of repeated blood transfusion: in favour of thalassemia

Osmotic fragility is reduced: in favour of thalassemia again though it may be seen in sickle cell also

Also, the hemoglobin is the question is more suggestive of severe anemia with positive history of multiple blood transfusions both being important pointers towards thalassemia major. Other ethnic groups having high prevalence of thalassemia are Punajbis, Sindhis, Gujaratis, Parsis, Begalis and Lohanas.

The above-mentioned points point to thalassemia. Since beta thalassemia is more prevalent, it is a better option than alpha thalassemia.

Explanation:

Option A. Alpha thalassemia typically presents with microcytic anemia and can be severe depending on the number of gene deletions but is less common in the Punjabi population.

Option C. Sickle cell anemia usually presents with normocytic anemia and not typically microcytic anemia. It can have target cells but is most commonly associated with the African population.

Option D. G6PD deficiency can lead to hemolytic anemia, often episodic and related to oxidative stress, but it typically does not cause a microcytic hypochromic anemia or a reduced MCV and MCHC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The  presentation of severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, a history of multiple blood transfusions, and reduced osmotic fragility in a child from an ethnicity with a high prevalence of thalassemia strongly suggests beta thalassemia major as the most likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Deletion of alpha genes
Deletion of beta genes
Excess of alpha genes
Single amino acid substitution in alpha chain

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of alpha thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deletion of alpha genes

Explanation:

Option A:

Deletion of alpha genes is the primary cause of alpha thalassemia. The number of deleted genes can affect the severity of the disease; the loss of two genes causes mild disease, while the loss of all four genes leads to hydrops fetalis.

Option B. Deletion of beta genes leads to beta thalassemia. This condition results from mutations in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11, not the alpha-globin gene on chromosome 16.

Option C. Excess of alpha genes does not cause alpha thalassemia. Typically, an imbalance between alpha and beta chains due to a relative lack of alpha genes is what causes thalassemias.

Option D. Single amino acid substitution in the alpha chain is commonly associated with hemoglobin variants like Hemoglobin C or S, but not with thalassemia, which is a quantitative problem with globin chain production.

Educational Objective:

Alpha thalassemia is most commonly caused by the deletion of alpha genes on chromosome 16, which leads to a quantitative reduction in the production of alpha-globin chains.

questions.text: NESTROF test is a screening test for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. β- thalassemia

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

β-thalassemia - NESTROFT is used to screen for beta-thalassemia because red blood cells in this condition exhibit reduced fragility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NESTROFT is a screening test for beta-thalassemia, which is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red blood cells in this condition.

 

The NESTROFT test (Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a simple, cheap screening test used especially in countries like India to screen for β-thalassemia trait (carrier state).

 

How it works:

 

  • Based on the principle that RBCs in thalassemia are microcytic and hypochromic → they have a reduced osmotic fragility (more resistant to lysis in hypotonic saline).
  • In the test:
    • A single hypotonic saline solution (usually around 0.36% NaCl) is used.
    • After incubation, if the solution remains turbid → positive test (RBCs did not lyse → likely β-thalassemia trait).
    • If the solution becomes clear → negative test (RBCs lysed → normal).

questions.text: A 30 years old female undergoes blood investigations which reveal RBC count 4.5 million, MCV 55fl and TLC 8000/mm3. There is no history of blood transfusion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thalassemia minor

 

Option C:

 

Thalassemia minor (beta-thalassemia trait) typically presents with mild to moderate microcytic, hypochromic anemia and a normal or slightly elevated RBC count.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic red cells, often with a high RDW and low serum ferritin levels.

 

Option B. Thalassemia major presents with severe microcytic anemia usually requiring blood transfusions for survival, often diagnosed in childhood.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytosis with an MCV typically greater than 100 fL due to impaired DNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with microcytic anemia and an MCV of 55 fL, a normal TLC, and no history of transfusion, thalassemia minor is likely, particularly when using indices such as the Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count), which is less than 13 in thalassemia minor.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 644

choices.text: Autosplenectomy
Bone marrow expansion in the calvarium
Effective erythropoeisis
Predisposition to *Hemophilus influenzae *infections

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is common to sickle cell anemia and thalassemia major?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bone marrow expansion in the calvarium

 

Option B:

 

Bone marrow expansion in the calvarium is a response to the increased erythropoietic demand in both sickle cell anemia and thalassemia major. This compensatory mechanism for chronic anemia causes a characteristic radiographic appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Autosplenectomy is the process of spleen shrinkage and fibrosis due to chronic damage, commonly seen in sickle cell anemia as a result of repeated vaso-occlusive episodes but is not a typical feature of thalassemia major.

 

Option C. Effective erythropoiesis refers to the production of functional red blood cells that successfully mature and enter circulation. This is not characteristic of either condition, as both sickle cell anemia and thalassemia major are marked by ineffective erythropoiesis resulting in inadequate functional red cell production.

 

Option D. Predisposition to Hemophilus influenzae infections is more commonly associated with asplenic or hyposplenic individuals, but it is not directly related to the bone marrow changes seen on skull x-rays.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both sickle cell anemia and thalassemia major can lead to bone marrow expansion in the calvarium as a compensatory response to increased erythropoietic demand due to chronic hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 640

choices.text: Sickle cell trait
Haemoglobin SC disease
Sickle thalassaemia
Sickle –Hb E disease

questions.text: One of the common variants of sickle cell anemia frequently marked by lesser degree of haemolytic anemia and greater propensity for the development of retinopathy and aseptic necrosis of bones is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sickle thalassaemia

 

Option C:

 

Sickle thalassaemia is one of the common variants of sickle cell anemia frequently marked by lesser degree of haemolytic anemia and greater propensity for the development of retinopathy and aseptic necrosis of bones

 

Sickle thalassemia is a coinheritance of a sickle cell gene and a thalassemia gene. It can present with a variable clinical picture, often with a lesser degree of hemolytic anemia but can have complications such as retinopathy and aseptic necrosis of bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sickle cell trait, the heterozygous form of sickle cell disease, usually causes no symptoms or a very mild clinical course and does not typically lead to complications like retinopathy or aseptic necrosis of bones.

 

Option B. Hemoglobin SC disease is a compound heterozygous condition with one sickle cell gene and one gene for hemoglobin C. It can present with a clinical picture similar to sickle cell disease but usually with a milder course.

 

Option D. Sickle-Hb E disease involves coinheritance of the sickle cell gene and hemoglobin E gene. It usually presents with milder symptoms compared to sickle cell anemia but can have clinical variability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle thalassemia often presents with less severe hemolytic anemia compared to sickle cell anemia but has a greater propensity for complications such as retinopathy and aseptic necrosis of bones.
